title: After Star Wars news, faith in ‘Game of Thrones’ showrunners David Benioff and D.B. Weiss is wavering
text:
AD

AD

Things don’t seem to be going well for the pair, though — at least not as well as logic would dictate they should. Each new headline about them feels increasingly negative. To say they’ve experienced a fall from grace would be a tremendous overstatement, but it’s safe to say that it’s (kind of) tough out there for a former GoT showrunner.

The latest news about the two came Monday night, when Deadline broke the story that the pair had “walked away from their much-publicized deal with Disney’s Lucasfilm to launch a feature film trilogy in 2022.”

Their first major post-GoT project was supposed to be launching the next series of Star Wars movies. The move made sense, given how they (generally) excelled at adapting Martin’s books. Both Star Wars and GoT are entire universes unto themselves, with myriad characters and a deep, self-contained mythology.

AD

AD

But the two said they don’t have time for the project, thanks to a nine-figure deal they signed with Netflix — though the streaming service is keeping any further details of the deal under wraps. (Like we said, it’s not all bad news.)

“There are only so many hours in the day, and we felt we could not do justice to both ‘Star Wars’ and our Netflix projects. So we are regretfully stepping away,” the duo told Deadline in a statement. “We love ‘Star Wars.’ When George Lucas built it, he built us too. Getting to talk about ‘Star Wars’ with him and the current ‘Star Wars’ team was the thrill of a lifetime, and we will always be indebted to the saga that changed everything.”

The news came just days after comments they made at the Austin Film Festival went semi-viral, and not in a way that would make their PR reps happy. Essentially, they reportedly said that they learned how to create a television show while … creating a massive television show.

AD

AD

“They acknowledge that they have no idea why after such a dismal ['Game of Thrones’] pilot why they went forward. ‘Everything we could make a mistake in, we did.’ Script, casting, costume. They think HBO went forward bc they had a lot of foreign presales on the series,” tweeted a writer who attended the panel. “Dan is saying that #GameofThrones was basically an expensive film school for he and Dave. For example, they had no idea how to work with costume designers, and it was a huge learning experience."

Given that the quotes came from one Twitter account and were later disseminated on blogs, they should be taken with a grain of salt. But the response to the revelations was telling. Accusations that Benioff and Weiss have primarily relied on “privilege” during their careers poured forth. One user referred to their comments as “basically White Male Privilege 101.”

The two news items are almost positively unrelated, but many on social media seemed to link the events.

AD

AD

“What a week it’s been for Benioff and Weiss,” tweeted Kevin Clancy, a Barstool Sports radio host. “They flat out admitted they didn’t know what they were doing on Thrones and then they lost ‘Star Wars.’ I’d imagine it’s not a good idea to admit you don’t know how to do a fantasy epic when you’ve signed on to do ‘Star Wars.'”

Public perception of the two creatives began souring in 2017 when they announced plans to create “Confederate,” a drama for HBO imagining a world where the South didn’t lose the Civil War. The hashtag #NoConfederate quickly began trending, reaching the No. 1 Twitter topic stateside and No. 2 worldwide. Culture critic Roxane Gay, writing in the New York Times, called the show “slavery fan fiction.”

Rather than outright cancel the project, Benioff and Weiss just sort of stopped talking about it — as did HBO, for the most part. The controversy died down, and the pair’s Netflix deal effectively — and quietly — ended “Confederate” two years later. Excitement grew for the final season of GoT, and all seemed well for the two.

AD

AD

Until it came out.

Fans and critics alike roundly criticized the show’s final season. As this reporter wrote in May: “More than 1.4 million people have signed a petition on Change.org asking HBO to ‘remake Game of Thrones Season 8 with competent writers.’ … I love this story, and I, like most of you, was crushed to see how the last season (and Season 7, let’s be real) has been handled.”

The Internet has a fairly brief collective memory, but the missteps seem to be piling up for Benioff and Weiss, though a nine-figure Netflix deal is about as good as it gets (aside from, you know, launching a new Star Wars trilogy).

But if the past gives us any indication, whatever they come up with will probably be scrutinized more than just about anything else on the platform.
